attributes.title: Exploring perceptions of opt-in and opt-out organ donation systems:  Study 1
attributes.description: This study has been designed to both probe participants current understanding of how organ donation works in Australia, and their perceptions of how organ donation would work under an alternative system.

TITLE: Exploring perceptions of opt-in and opt-out organ donation systems:  Study 1

AUTHORS: Authors: Barbara Masser, Melissa Hyde, & Eamonn Ferguson

AFFILIATIONS: Masser & Hyde: The University of Queensland, Australia; Ferguson: University of Nottingham, UK.

Last updated: 10 December 2019

Contact information: For more information, please contact Barbara Masser (b.masser@psy.uq.edu.au) or Mel Hyde (m.hyde@uq.edu.au).

BACKGROUND
England is moving to a ‘soft’ opt-out system as of April 1 2020.  Because of this it is likely that the debate about Australia’s organ donation system will re-ignite with questions raised as to whether Australia should follow the UK’s lead (in the belief that this will lead to a greater number of organs donated upon death).  Although the move towards considering opt-out has occurred before in Australia,[1-2] there is limited recent evidence as to what people know and believe about the different systems of organ donation.  Further, as ‘soft’ opt-out systems where the explicit consent of the family for organ retrieval is still required are frequently misperceived as ‘hard’ opt-out systems (where explicit family consent is not required), any move to a ‘soft’ opt-out system may lead to fewer people registering their wishes with the Australian Organ Donor Register, having conversations with family members about their organ donation preference prior to death, and donating their organs while living.  

In 2015, Wales was the first country in the UK to move to a soft opt-out system with the target to increase the number of organ donors by 25%, a figure that is consistent with the 20% increase in donor rates reported in other countries with soft opt-out systems.[3] An observational study comparing the 3 years prior and 18 months after the legislation change showed that while consent rates increased to 61% overall (UK consent rates also increased to 63.1% in this period), the numbers of deceased donors did not increase.[4] Organ donation registration increased by 4% (from 34% to 38%), with 6% registering not to donate.[4] Approaches to family during this time period showed that they still sought to override their loved one’s organ donation decision and found the concept of deemed consent to be complicated and difficult to understand.[5] The 2018 Annual Organ Donation report from the Welsh Government showed a fall in the number of living donors (-14%) and patients receiving transplants (-8%) after the legislation change.[6] Further, the 2019 Welsh public attitudes to organ donation survey reported that only 55% of people have had family discussions about organ donation, representing a 5% increase after legislation change.[7] Collectively, these figures suggest that any move to a soft opt-out system in Australia may have the same unintended consequences as observed in Wales.  Specifically, that organ donation rates may fall as families refuse to consent to organ retrieval because they are unsure of the potential donor’s wishes, fewer people choosing to be living donors due to a misperception that the demand-supply gap for organs has been met, and little change in the numbers of potential donors registering their decision on the Australian Organ Donor Register or telling their family their organ donation preference.

A second issue arising with a move to an opt-out system is with regard to the nature of the contribution that the donor is seen to make through donating.  Organ donation, rightly or wrongly, has often been characterised as a ‘gift’ that the donor (and their family) make to another person.[8] While this can lead to the expectation of gratitude from the recipient to the donor’s family, a number of analyses suggest that organ donation in an opt-in system can have additional ongoing benefits for the donor’s family and the legacy of the donor themselves.  That is, by ‘gifting’ an organ the grieving process can be eased as families take comfort in perceiving that some good has come out of their relative’s death.  Further, donors’ families come to regard their relative as (more) special and as someone to be proud of for their selfless act.  These perceived ‘benefits’ to donating may change if the system for donating changes from opt-in to opt-out (c.f. Noyes et al[4]).[9] Specifically, the assumed default that everyone will donate in an opt-out system means that those who donate will no longer be seen as special, while those who refuse to donate may be seen less positively. Such a change in perceptions about organ donation may have further flow-on effects in decreasing the number of people willing to donate and the number of families willing to consent to donation in an opt-out system.

We propose an in-depth exploration of current understanding of and attitudes towards organ donation systems amongst members of the general Australian community in order to provide key information for organ donation stakeholders, policy makers, and health professionals, in the event that changes in the organ donation system are considered or come into effect in the future.

RESEARCH QUESTIONS

Current Understanding
1.	How do members of the general community believe that organ donation currently works in Australia’s opt-in system?
a.	What percentage of adults do members of the general community believe die in a way such that their organs can be donated?
b.	What percentage of adults who die in a way such that their organs can be donated do members of the general community believe would actually end up donating their organs?
c.	How do adult members of the general community feel about those who donate their organs in the current system?

2.	If Australia instead had a soft opt-out system (as England will in 2020), how do members of the general community believe that organ donation will work under such a system?
a.	What percentage of adults do members of the general community believe will die in a way such that their organs can be donated?
b.	What percentage of those who die in a way such that their organs can be donated do members of the general community believe would actually end up donating their organs?
c.	How do members of the general community feel about those who donate their organs in a soft opt-out system?

Comparison between alternative systems
3.	When accurate information is given about soft opt-out and opt-in systems, what percentage of adults (defined as those aged 18 or above) who die in a way that makes them eligible to become organ donors do members of the general community expect will become organ donors?
4.	When accurate information is given about soft opt-out and opt-in systems, what percentage of adults do members of the general community think will have registered their intention (to donate or not donate) with the Australian Organ Donor Register?
5.	When accurate information is given about soft opt-out and opt-in systems, what percentage of adults do members of the general community think will have discussed their intention (to donate or not to donate) with their family and/or close relatives?
6.	When accurate information is given about soft opt-out and opt-in systems, what percentage of adults do members of the general community think will be a living kidney donor (to a loved one or stranger)?

PROJECT DESIGN
This study will explore current understanding of organ donation in Australia and explore perceptions and understanding of the existing opt-in donation system in Australia and of a soft opt-out system.  Following the provision of accurate information about opt-in and soft opt-out systems, participants perceptions of others’ donation related behaviours will be explored. 

Hypotheses 
1.	The estimates of those registering for the first time and discussing their decision to donate or not to donate will be higher under an opt-in system than under a soft opt-out system. 
2.	The estimates of the number of people whose organs are suitable for transplant who go on to donate will be higher under a soft opt-out system than under an opt-in system. 
3.	The estimates of those donating their kidney while living to a loved one or stranger will be higher under an opt-in system than under a soft opt-out system. 

SAMPLE CHARACTERISTICS, SIZE, AND DERIVATION
Adults will be eligible to participate in the study if they are aged over 18 years and are Australian citizens. Eligible participants will be recruited to the study via the Prolific Academic online panel (limited to the Australian cohort), UQ student and community networks (e.g., recruited through the School of Psychology Student Participation scheme), and/or Australian residents in the general community (e.g., snowball sampling).   We will aim for a sample of participants that is 50% male, 50% female in composition and that comprises participants of a range of ages. 

Lin et al.[10] reports effect sizes ranging from small (e.g., d = 0.16) to moderate (e.g., eta-squared = 0.16).  Adopting Cohen’s norms of small and medium effect sizes, we adopted a small to moderate f value of 0.18, to determine the required sample size for the study using G* power.[11] 
Based on an estimated effect size of f = 0.18 with a specified alpha level of .05, and a power level of .90, for a between-subjects ANOVA with three levels, the analysis indicated a total required sample size range of 396.

MATERIALS

Measures
Prior to consenting to participate in the study all participants will be provided a Participant Information Sheet which outlines the aims and requirements of the study. The study will include questions about participant age, gender, and registration status on the Australian Organ Donor Register, as well as personal experience with transplantation and donation. Participants will be asked to provide a unique identifier to ensure all participants can be appropriately compensated (e.g. course credit, monetary) in a way which maintains participant anonymity. Demographic questions are presented at the end of the survey. Where possible, established measures used in previous organ donation studies or questions based on prior research findings will be used for the remaining measures. 
The study will assess participant knowledge of the current opt-in donation system in Australia. Those who correctly perceive the current system will be randomly assigned to answer questions on the following topics for either the current opt-in system or a soft opt-out system: 
•	the number of people who die in a way that makes organ donation possible and actually become organ donors within this system; 
•	demand for living donors and the number of people who donate while living (adapted from [6]); and
•	how many people communicate their donation decision within this system (register, discuss)[6].   
Further all those who participate in this study will be asked their perceptions about and attitudes towards organ donors (adapted from [12-15]), myths about organ donation,[16-18] and perceived effectiveness of donation systems and why. 

ANALYSIS PLAN

Demographics
Demographic characteristics of respondents will be analysed using appropriate statistics (e.g., counts, means, standard deviations etc) in order to describe the sample obtained.

Q1-2 
Appropriate descriptive statistics (e.g., percentages) and analyses (e.g., chi-square) will be generated to illustrate respondent’s knowledge of the current opt-in system of organ donation and (for those allocated to this condition) their perception of how a soft opt-out system would operate.

Q3-13 
Responses to these questions will be analysed using an independent groups t-test comparing those in the opt-in vs those in the soft opt-out condition. 

Exploratory factor analysis will be conducted on responses to Q11, Q12, and Q13.  If the results of this analysis indicate that appropriate composite scales can be created that are internally reliable (determined by Cronbach’s alpha of >.7) then composite scales representing responses to Q11, Q12 and Q13 will be generated.  Responses to these scales will be analysed using a one-way ANOVA comparing those in the randomised opt-in vs those in the soft opt-out condition along with those who incorrectly identified the current system of organ donation in operation in Australia.  If significant differences are observed then these will be followed up with the appropriate post hoc analysis (e.g. Tukey HSD test) with an adjustment for multiple comparisons made to the p value.

Q14
Responses to Q14 will be described (mean, standard deviation).

Q15
Responses to Q15 by group (opt-in, soft opt-out, misperception of current system in Australia) will be explored via chi-square.  Qualitative responses will be coded using thematic analysis by the investigators.

Exploratory analyses
Responses to the key focal outcomes will be explored as a function of a range of demographic characteristics (e.g., gender, age, experience with organ transplant etc). This will be conducted in order to advance our understanding of demographic characteristics that may impact perceptions of organ donation under the different systems described. 

DATA COLLECTION
Data collection is nearing completion (expected completion Feb 2020).

ETHICS
This study was granted Human Research Ethics Approval from The University of Queensland on the 30th September 2019. Participation is entirely voluntary, and participants are free to withdraw at any time. A summary of the results of the study for Participants will be freely accessible on the Donor Research Network website after study completion.

REFERENCES
1.	Delriviere L, Boronovskis H. (February 2011). Adopting an opt-out registration system for organ and tissue donation in Western Australia: A discussion paper. http://www.parliament.wa.gov.au/publications/tabledpapers.nsf/displaypaper/3813336a792bbc8b9d40d54248257896000a9a44/$file/3336.pdf Accessed 16th July, 2019.
2.	Isdale W, Savulescu J. Three proposals to increase Australia’s organ supply. Monash Bioethics Review. 2015;33(2-3):91-101.
3.	Stephens M. Opt-out organ donation systems—the experience in Wales. Journal of Kidney Care. 2018;3(1):38-40.
4.	Noyes J, McLaughlin L, Morgan K, Walton P, Curtis R, Madden S, et al. Short-term impact of introducing a soft opt-out organ donation system in Wales: before and after study. BMJ Open. 2019 Apr 1;9(4):e025159.
5.	Mc Laughlin L, Noyes J, Morgan K, Walton P, Roberts A, Stephens M. Family attitudes, actions, decisions and experiences following implementation of deemed consent and the Human Transplantation Act (Wales) 2013 [Abstract]. Transplantation. 2018; 10(7S):S288.
6.	Welsh Government. (2018). Together for health: Organ donation annual report 2018. https://gov.wales/sites/default/files/publications/2018-12/organ-donation-annual-report-2018.pdf Accessed 16th July, 2019.
7.	Welsh Government Social Research. (2019). Update to survey of public attitudes to organ donation: Key figures from Wave 16. https://gov.wales/sites/default/files/statistics-and-research/2019-04/public-attitudes-organ-donation-wave-16-key-figures.pdf  Accessed 17th July, 2019. 
8.	Moloney G, Sutherland M, Norton M, Walker I. When is the gift given? Organ donation, social representations, and an opportunity to register. Journal of Community & Applied Social Psychology. 2019;29(3):207–21.
9.	Carr-Hill RA. Organ donation in Wales. Br J Gen Pract. 2018 Mar;68(668):119–20.
10.	Lin Y, Osman M, Harris AJL, Read D. Underlying wishes and nudged choices. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Applied. 2018 Dec;24(4):459–75.
11.	Faul F, Erdfelder E, Lang AG, Buchner A. G* Power 3: A flexible statistical power analysis program for the social, behavioral, and biomedical sciences. Behavior research methods. 2007;39(2):175-191.
12.	Fredrickson BL, Tugade MM, Waugh CE, Larkin GR. What good are positive emotions in crisis? A prospective study of resilience and emotions following the terrorist attacks on the United States on September 11th, 2001. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. 2003;84(2):365–76.
13.	Kentish-Barnes N, Cohen-Solal Z, Souppart V, Cheisson G, Joseph L, Martin-Lefèvre L, et al. Being Convinced and Taking Responsibility: A Qualitative Study of Family Members’ Experience of Organ Donation Decision and Bereavement After Brain Death*. Critical Care Medicine. 2019 Apr;47(4):526–34.
14.	Sque M, Payne SA. Dissonant loss: The experiences of donor relatives. Social Science & Medicine. 1996 Nov 1;43(9):1359–70.
15.	Sque M, Walker W, Long-Sutehall T, Morgan M, Randhawa G, Rodney A. Bereaved donor families’ experiences of organ and tissue donation, and perceived influences on their decision making. J Crit Care. 2018;45:82–9.
16.	Miller J, Currie S, O’Carroll RE. ‘What if I’m not dead?’ – Myth-busting and organ donation. British Journal of Health Psychology. 2019;24(1):141–58.
17.	Hyde MK, Wihardjo KR, White KM. Do the myths still exist? Revisiting people’s negative beliefs about organ donation upon death. Psychology, Health & Medicine. 2012;17(5):530-41.
18.	Harel I, Kogut T, Pinchas M, Slovic P. Effect of media presentations on willingness to commit to organ donation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. 2017 May 16;114(20):5159–64.

attributes.title: The Reliability and Validity of the Open Enneagram of Personality Scales

q1.value: Reliability and Validity of the Open Enneagram of Personality Scales

q3.value:
A psychometric study will look at the reliability and validity of the Open Enneagram of Personality Scale (OEPS). Reliability will be assessed through test-retest reliability and internal consistency reliability. Validity will be assessed through factor analysis and correlating the OEPS with a Big Five Personality Scale. Similar research has been done on other Enneagram assessments such as Wagner Enneagram of Personality Style Scale, Riso-Hudson Enneagram Type Inventory, and the Nine Types Temperament Model. The purpose of this study will be to perform similar studies on the free OEPS to see if it is a adequate alternative to these other costly assessments. 

RQ1: Is the OEPS a reliable measure to assess personality?
RQ2: Is the OEPS a valid measure to assess personality?
RQ3: Do those with more knowledge of the Enneagram have higher consistency with responses?

q4.value:
RQ1 Hypothesis 
1. I hypothesize that there will be a correlation greater than 0.70 between time 1 and time 2 on OEPS types. 
2. I hypothesize that the Cronbach Alpha coefficient will be greater than .70 for all nine Enneagram types.
RQ2 Hypothesis 
3. Conscientiousness should correlate positively with Type 1 and negatively correlate with Type 7. 
4. Extroversion should correlate positively with Type 2, Type 3, Type 7, and Type 8 and negatively correlate with Type 5 and Type 6. 
5. Neuroticism should positively correlate with Type 4 and Type 6. 
6. Agreeableness will correlate positively with type 9 and negatively correlate with Type 5 and Type 8. 
7. Openness to Experience will positively correlate with Type 7. 
8. I hypothesize that the OEPS will not produce a 9-factor model when performing factor analysis. 
RQ3 Hypothesis 
9. Those with higher knowledge of the Enneagram will have higher internal consistency than those with less knowledge of the Enneagram.

question.value: A convenience sample will be obtained through a medium sized religious university, online social media participants, and through Amazon Mechanical Turk. Participants are selected from many groups in order to ensure a large sample. Those on Amazon Mechanical Turk will be given $0.05 for taking the survey. The survey will be sent out to those on university campus through email and shared online through social media. Those taking the second survey will be put in a drawing to win a $25 gift card. Data collection will commence upon IRB approval and will continue for two weeks. Six months after initial assessment, participants will be contacted again through email to take the survey again to assess test-retest reliability. The second assessment will contain the OEPS but not the Big Five Inventory. This second assessment will last for two additional weeks. We would like to receive over 270 participants. Participants for time 2 will be obtained from all participants who provided email from time 1.

question.value: N/A no manipulated variables in my study.

Enneagram Type: Type 1 (the reformer), Type 2 (the helper), Type 3 (the achiever), Type 4 (the individualist), Type 5 (the investigator), Type 6 (the loyalist), Type 7 (the enthusiast), Type 8 (the challenger), Type 9 (the peacemaker)
Big Five Personality: Contentiousness, Extroversion, Agreeableness, Openness to Experience, Neuroticism
The knowledge of the Enneagram on a scale from 1 to 5 (1- knows nothing about it; 5-much knowledge on types and theory)

Enneagram: 
All nine type have 4 statements (36 questions total) each with a scale from 1 to 5 on how much they agree with the statement  (1-disagree; 5-agree) (Development of the OSPP Enneagram of Personality Scales, 2019).
Big Five Personality: 
44 statements using a scale 1 to 5 on how much they agree with the statement (1-strongly disagree; 5- strongly agree). 8 statements associated with extraversion. 9 statements associated with agreeableness.  9 statements associated with contentiousness. 8 statements associated with neuroticism. 10 statements associated with openness to experience (John & Srivastava, 1999).

RQ1 Hypothesis 
1. I hypothesize that there will be a correlation greater than 0.70 between time 1 and time 2 on OEPS types. (Pearson's correlation)
2. I hypothesize that the Cronbach Alpha coefficient will be greater than .70 for all nine Enneagram types.
RQ2 Hypothesis 
3. Conscientiousness should correlate positively with Type 1 and negatively correlate with Type 7. (Pearson's correlation)
4. Extroversion should correlate positively with Type 2, Type 3, Type 7, and Type 8 and negatively correlate with Type 5 and Type 6. (Pearson's correlation)
5. Neuroticism should positively correlate with Type 4 and Type 6. (Pearson's correlation)
6. Agreeableness will correlate positively with type 9 and negatively correlate with Type 5 and Type 8. (Pearson's correlation)
7. Openness to Experience will positively correlate with Type 7. (Pearson's correlation)
8. I hypothesize that the OEPS will not produce a 9-factor model when performing factor analysis. 
RQ3 Hypothesis 
9. Those with higher knowledge of the Enneagram will have higher internal consistency than those with less knowledge of the Enneagram. (Pearson's correlation)

q20.value: no transformations will be done, but reverse-scored items will be re-coded as per author's directions.

q21.value: overall, all p-values will be less than .05. Bonferroni correction will be used. All tests will be one-tailed tests.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they fail the quality check items. Two questions exist which tell participants to check "strongly agree" or "strongly disagree." Participants who exhibit atypical responses to three or four questions will also be excluded.

q23.value: missing data or incomplete data will not be included in analysis.

q24.value: We will look for demographic difference between Enneagram types. We will also look for relationships between Enneagram types and Big Five traits that we did not predict.

attributes.title: Effects of labels on morality judgements in adults
attributes.description: We are looking at how adults' perceptions of acceptability of moral, immoral and cultural actions changes if we add a familiar or unfamiliar label. We are also looking at the effect levels of neighborhood diversity has on their ratings.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
a.	Domain type (Direct moral, Direct immoral, Indirect moral, Indirect immoral, Western, Foreign) is a within-subject variable.
b.	Label (Familiar vs unfamiliar label) is a within-subject variable 
c.	Demographic variables are between-subject variables that are parent-reported. 
▪	Participant race (7 distinct racial categories and 8th category for bi- or multi-racial)
▪	Language exposure 
●	Native language (3 categories: English, English-Other language, and Other language)
●	Regularly hears another language (yes vs. no)
●	We will group participants into the following categories based on the above two questions: (1) bilingual: has more than one native language; (2) exposure: has only one native language but regularly hears other languages; (3) no exposure: has only one native language and does not regularly hear other languages. 
▪	Intergroup contact
●	Quantity of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
●	Pleasantness of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
●	Quantity of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
●	Pleasantness of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
▪	Religiosity: level of religiosity question asked from the General Social Survey’s religiosity question (RELPERSN) 1 = very religious to 4 = not religious at all. 
▪	Neighborhood trust: sum of responses from “social cohesion and trust” and “informal control” scales from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). (9 to 45; greater number = greater trust)
▪	Educational Level:
●	Participant highest level of education (1= 8th grade of less to 7 = graduate or professional degree)
▪	Neighborhood demographics according to zip code
●	Zip code
●	Linguistic diversity in zip code: 2 measures
o	% of linguistic outgroup speakers (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s language speakers reported in the latest American Community Survey (ACS) from 100%
▪	e.g., for a monolingual English speaker, this will the % of non-English speakers; for a bilingual Spanish-English speaker, this will be the % of English & Spanish speakers subtracted from 100% 
o	Entropy of linguistic diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different language groups accounting for proportion) that uses the number of and proportion of language groups from ACS and is calculated using the R package “entropy” (Hausser & Strimme, 2009)
●	Racial diversity in zip code: 2 measures
o	% of racial outgroup population (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s race population reported in ACS from 100%.
▪	e.g., for a Black participant, this will be the % of non-Black population calculated by subtracting the proportion of Black population reported in ACS from 100%
o	Entropy of racial diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different race groups accounting for proportion) that is calculated the same way as entropy of linguistic diversity but uses ACS on race instead.
●	Sum the proportion of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population” composite score (0% to 200%) 
●	Sum the entropy of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population entropy” composite score 
●	Median income in zip code (continuous) that is extracted directly from ACS 
●	Population density in zip code (number of people per square mile) that is extracted directly from the latest US census

question2b.value: Acceptability rating: Rating of how acceptable the action is (1 = really not okay to 5 = really okay)

question3b.value:
d.	Gender may affect responses. We will conduct a preliminary analysis to see if there are any gender differences by conducting an ANOVA with gender (between-subject) as the IV and acceptability rating as DV. If there are significant gender differences, we will include gender as a covariate in our subsequent analyses. 
e.	We will check to see if there are effects of our counterbalancing (Condition A vs. B). Every participant will see half unfamiliar half familiar labels and we counterbalanced which items were labeled familiar or unfamiliar across the two conditions. We will conduct a preliminary analysis using an ANOVA using Condition (between-subject) as the IV and acceptability rating as the DV. We expect there to be no difference. If there is, we will include condition as a covariate in our subsequent analyses. 
f.	Age may affect analyses so we will include it as a covariate in our analyses.

question10b.value:
Participants will view four items each of direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western actions. Items will be presented in a random order. All actions will have an accompanying picture, two sentence description, and a 5-point scale to indicate how okay it is to perform this action (see Figure 1 for the scale; see supplementary attachment for Qualtrics surveys). For the direct and indirect moral and immoral actions and western customs, half of the items will be accompanied with unfamiliar labels, which are words created by reversing the novel words from the Novel Noun Database (Horst & Hout, in press). The other half will be accompanied with familiar labels, which are English labels that already exist to describe these actions. For foreign customs, half of the items are the descriptive labels used in the language of the country of origin (i.e., unfamiliar labels), whereas the other half of the items are English words describing the intent of the foreign customs (i.e., familiar labels). See Table 1 for the labels and descriptions. Which items are labeled with familiar labels or unfamiliar labels will be counterbalanced across participants. Participants will also complete a demographic survey. 
Demographic information. Participants will provide their age, gender, race/ethnicity, language background, current zip code and highest level of education. 
Familiarity. Participants will provide how familiar they are with the foreign and western actions on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal). 
Intergroup contact. Participants will complete four questions on the quantity and quality of contact they have with people who speak different languages and people who are of a different race from them. These questions were derived from the General Intergroup Contact Quantity and Contact Quality (Islam & Hewstone, 1993).  
Neighborhood trust. Participants will complete the social cohesion and trust scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
Religiosity. Participants will complete a question on their level of religiosity from the 2016 General Demographic Survey. 

Procedure
Participants will access the Qualtrics survey via Amazon Mturk and will judge on a 5-point scale the items presented. After finishing the acceptability ratings, they will complete the demographic forms. At the end, they will receive an MTurk completion code which serves as their subject identifier and also serves as their means to receive compensation (1 US dollar).

question6b.value:
We used a cohen's d estimate of a medium effect size (0.06 eta squared) for the main Label x Domain interaction. We used G*Power to conduct power analysis. G*Power gave us a total sample size of 316 participants at alpha 0.05 with 95% power to detect this main interaction. 

Diversity and religiosity effects: Due to the uncertainty of how to estimate the effect size of diversity and religiosity, we will collect the appropriate sample size and analyze data only after we determine the diversity and religiosity effect sizes from this data. We will create a second pre-registration before analyzing questions related to diversity and religiosity.

question8b.value:
a.	If participants respond with the same response for all items (e.g., participant only chose “okay” for all items) that participant will not be included in the final sample 
b.	For each participant, we will exclude any foreign items that participants rate as much familiar (score of 4) or higher from analyses. We will exclude any western items that participants rate as little familiar (score of 2) or lower from analyses. 
c.	If the response took too short of a time (i.e., less than 1 minute to complete the survey) that participant will be excluded

question1a.value:
1.	Domain effect:
a.	We hypothesize that adults will judge direct immoral actions (i.e., actions that result in direct physical or psychological harm) as less acceptable than indirect immoral actions (i.e., actions that do not result in direct harm but are frowned upon) or foreign customs (i.e., actions from cultures unfamiliar to the participants but do not cause any physical or psychological harm). We hypothesize that foreign customs will be judged as more acceptable than indirect immoral actions. 
b.	We hypothesize that adults will judge direct moral actions (i.e., actions that are directly helpful), indirect moral actions (i.e., actions that are seen as polite or in line with the rules), and western customs (i.e., actions participants are familiar with from their own culture) as equally acceptable. Direct moral actions should be seen as more acceptable than direct immoral and indirect immoral actions. Indirect moral actions will be seen as more acceptable than indirect immoral actions. Western customs will be seen as more acceptable than foreign customs.  

2.	Label x Domain interaction effect: 
a.	We hypothesize that adults will judge foreign customs as more acceptable when these actions are described with familiar labels than unfamiliar labels. 
b.	We hypothesize that immoral and indirect immoral actions will be judged as more acceptable when labelled with unfamiliar labels than familiar labels. 
c.	We do not expect any labels effect on direct moral and direct immoral actions. 

3.	Diversity effect: 
a.	We predict that adults with exposure to higher levels of racial and linguistic diversity (as quantified from US census data using zip codes) will be more open to foreign customs than adults with exposure to lower levels of racial and linguistic diversity. We also predict that the level of neighborhood trust will be a moderating factor, such that adults from neighborhoods with higher levels of racial and linguistic diversity and higher levels of trust will show greater openness than those with higher levels of racial and linguistic diversity but lower levels of trust. 
b.	We predict that neighborhood racial and linguistic diversity and trust will not affect adults’ judgments of direct immoral, direct moral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, and western customs.
c.	Exposure to outgroups will be measured in two ways: (1) by using zip code based census data and (2) by using self-report measures. We will test whether neighborhood zip code-based outgroup exposure is more predictive than self-report measures of outgroup contact quantity and quality.
i.	We will examine whether exposure to linguistic outgroup (i.e., people who speak a different language from the participant) or racial outgroup (i.e., people who are of a different race than the participant) are more predictive of acceptability. We will also test whether it is just simple exposure to outgroups (i.e., anyone who is different) or variety of exposure to different types of outgroups that matter more.
ii.	We will also explore whether PCA separates exposure to outgroup population versus neighborhood trust (or self-reported contact quality).  We will test whether PCA components are more predictive than our composite measures of exposure to outgroup. 

4.	Religiosity effect: We predict that adults from families with higher levels of religiosity (as measured by self-report) will judge indirect immoral actions and foreign customs as less acceptable than adults from families with lower levels of religiosity.

question2a.value: See section 2 Label x Domain interaction effect.

question3a.value: As a manipulation check, we will ask participants to rate their familiarity with western and foreign customs and use these ratings to ensure participants are clearly distinguishing these items as familiar and unfamiliar (see confirmatory analyses section for details).

question1c.value:
1.	Familiarity check: We predict that participants will rate western actions as more familiar than foreign ones. 
a. For each participant, we will exclude acceptability ratings of a foreign item that has a familiarity rating of much familiar or higher (i.e., score of 4 or higher). Reversely, if any western items are rated as little familiar or lower (i.e., score of 2 or lower) those items will be excluded. These cleaned ratings will then be used as the dv in the following analyses. 	
b. We will conduct an ANOVA with domain type (foreign and western; within-subject variable) as the predictor and familiarity ratings by participants (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) as the dv. 	

2.	Domain type and label effects. 
• We will conduct a repeated measure ANOVA as specified below. 
a.	Acceptability ratings will be averaged for each participant in each domain and each label condition.

question2c.value: We will conduct a repeated measure ANOVA with label type (familiar versus unfamiliar; within-subject) and domain type (direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western; within-subject) as predictors and the acceptability ratings as the dv. If Mauchly’s test of sphericity are violated, we will use Greenhouse-Geisser corrections. Significant interactions will be further investigated using Holm-corrected post-hoc tests.

question3c.value:
IV: Label and domain type
DV: acceptability ratings

question4c.value:
If  gender and condition were significant from our preliminary analyses, we will include them as covariate. If they are not, we will not include them.

Age in years will be included as a covariate.

a.	Religiosity (1 to 4 self-report), label type, (familiar versus unfamiliar; within-subject), domain type (direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western; within-subject), and age

Significant interactions among these variables will be further explored using simple slope analyses.

registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
a.	Domain type (Direct moral, Direct immoral, Indirect moral, Indirect immoral, Western, Foreign) is a within-subject variable.
b.	Label (Familiar vs unfamiliar label) is a within-subject variable 
c.	Demographic variables are between-subject variables that are parent-reported. 
▪	Participant race (7 distinct racial categories and 8th category for bi- or multi-racial)
▪	Language exposure 
●	Native language (3 categories: English, English-Other language, and Other language)
●	Regularly hears another language (yes vs. no)
●	We will group participants into the following categories based on the above two questions: (1) bilingual: has more than one native language; (2) exposure: has only one native language but regularly hears other languages; (3) no exposure: has only one native language and does not regularly hear other languages. 
▪	Intergroup contact
●	Quantity of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
●	Pleasantness of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
●	Quantity of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
●	Pleasantness of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
▪	Religiosity: level of religiosity question asked from the General Social Survey’s religiosity question (RELPERSN) 1 = very religious to 4 = not religious at all. 
▪	Neighborhood trust: sum of responses from “social cohesion and trust” and “informal control” scales from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). (9 to 45; greater number = greater trust)
▪	Educational Level:
●	Participant highest level of education (1= 8th grade of less to 7 = graduate or professional degree)
▪	Neighborhood demographics according to zip code
●	Zip code
●	Linguistic diversity in zip code: 2 measures
o	% of linguistic outgroup speakers (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s language speakers reported in the latest American Community Survey (ACS) from 100%
▪	e.g., for a monolingual English speaker, this will the % of non-English speakers; for a bilingual Spanish-English speaker, this will be the % of English & Spanish speakers subtracted from 100% 
o	Entropy of linguistic diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different language groups accounting for proportion) that uses the number of and proportion of language groups from ACS and is calculated using the R package “entropy” (Hausser & Strimme, 2009)
●	Racial diversity in zip code: 2 measures
o	% of racial outgroup population (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s race population reported in ACS from 100%.
▪	e.g., for a Black participant, this will be the % of non-Black population calculated by subtracting the proportion of Black population reported in ACS from 100%
o	Entropy of racial diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different race groups accounting for proportion) that is calculated the same way as entropy of linguistic diversity but uses ACS on race instead.
●	Sum the proportion of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population” composite score (0% to 200%) 
●	Sum the entropy of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population entropy” composite score 
●	Median income in zip code (continuous) that is extracted directly from ACS 
●	Population density in zip code (number of people per square mile) that is extracted directly from the latest US census
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: Acceptability rating: Rating of how acceptable the action is (1 = really not okay to 5 = really okay)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
d.	Gender may affect responses. We will conduct a preliminary analysis to see if there are any gender differences by conducting an ANOVA with gender (between-subject) as the IV and acceptability rating as DV. If there are significant gender differences, we will include gender as a covariate in our subsequent analyses. 
e.	We will check to see if there are effects of our counterbalancing (Condition A vs. B). Every participant will see half unfamiliar half familiar labels and we counterbalanced which items were labeled familiar or unfamiliar across the two conditions. We will conduct a preliminary analysis using an ANOVA using Condition (between-subject) as the IV and acceptability rating as the DV. We expect there to be no difference. If there is, we will include condition as a covariate in our subsequent analyses. 
f.	Age may affect analyses so we will include it as a covariate in our analyses.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants will view four items each of direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western actions. Items will be presented in a random order. All actions will have an accompanying picture, two sentence description, and a 5-point scale to indicate how okay it is to perform this action (see Figure 1 for the scale; see supplementary attachment for Qualtrics surveys). For the direct and indirect moral and immoral actions and western customs, half of the items will be accompanied with unfamiliar labels, which are words created by reversing the novel words from the Novel Noun Database (Horst & Hout, in press). The other half will be accompanied with familiar labels, which are English labels that already exist to describe these actions. For foreign customs, half of the items are the descriptive labels used in the language of the country of origin (i.e., unfamiliar labels), whereas the other half of the items are English words describing the intent of the foreign customs (i.e., familiar labels). See Table 1 for the labels and descriptions. Which items are labeled with familiar labels or unfamiliar labels will be counterbalanced across participants. Participants will also complete a demographic survey. 
Demographic information. Participants will provide their age, gender, race/ethnicity, language background, current zip code and highest level of education. 
Familiarity. Participants will provide how familiar they are with the foreign and western actions on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal). 
Intergroup contact. Participants will complete four questions on the quantity and quality of contact they have with people who speak different languages and people who are of a different race from them. These questions were derived from the General Intergroup Contact Quantity and Contact Quality (Islam & Hewstone, 1993).  
Neighborhood trust. Participants will complete the social cohesion and trust scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
Religiosity. Participants will complete a question on their level of religiosity from the 2016 General Demographic Survey. 

Procedure
Participants will access the Qualtrics survey via Amazon Mturk and will judge on a 5-point scale the items presented. After finishing the acceptability ratings, they will complete the demographic forms. At the end, they will receive an MTurk completion code which serves as their subject identifier and also serves as their means to receive compensation (1 US dollar).
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
1.	Familiarity check: We predict that participants will rate western actions as more familiar than foreign ones. 
a. For each participant, we will exclude acceptability ratings of a foreign item that has a familiarity rating of much familiar or higher (i.e., score of 4 or higher). Reversely, if any western items are rated as little familiar or lower (i.e., score of 2 or lower) those items will be excluded. These cleaned ratings will then be used as the dv in the following analyses. 	
b. We will conduct an ANOVA with domain type (foreign and western; within-subject variable) as the predictor and familiarity ratings by participants (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) as the dv. 	

2.	Domain type and label effects. 
• We will conduct a repeated measure ANOVA as specified below. 
a.	Acceptability ratings will be averaged for each participant in each domain and each label condition.

We will conduct a repeated measure ANOVA with label type (familiar versus unfamiliar; within-subject) and domain type (direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western; within-subject) as predictors and the acceptability ratings as the dv. If Mauchly’s test of sphericity are violated, we will use Greenhouse-Geisser corrections. Significant interactions will be further investigated using Holm-corrected post-hoc tests.

IV: Label and domain type
DV: acceptability ratings

If  gender and condition were significant from our preliminary analyses, we will include them as covariate. If they are not, we will not include them.

Age in years will be included as a covariate.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: Diversity effects: We will specify our plan for analyzing the diversity effects after completing this study and examining the domain type x label effects. We will create a second pre-registration to specify these effects.

b.	Located in the U.S.
c.	Have an approval rating of 75% or greater from Amazon Turk
d.	Correctly answer CAPTCHA question (bot detection)
a.	from Amazon Mturk using a Qualtrics survey link

We used a cohen's d estimate of a medium effect size (0.06 eta squared) for the main Label x Domain interaction. We used G*Power to conduct power analysis. G*Power gave us a total sample size of 316 participants at alpha 0.05 with 95% power to detect this main interaction. 

Diversity and religiosity effects: Due to the uncertainty of how to estimate the effect size of diversity and religiosity, we will collect the appropriate sample size and analyze data only after we determine the diversity and religiosity effect sizes from this data. We will create a second pre-registration before analyzing questions related to diversity and religiosity.
c.	Once the planned sample size is reached, data collection will be stopped.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: a.	Religiosity (1 to 4 self-report), label type, (familiar versus unfamiliar; within-subject), domain type (direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western; within-subject), and age

We will conduct a linear regression with religiosity (1 to 4), label type, (familiar versus unfamiliar; within-subject), domain type (direct moral, direct immoral, indirect moral, indirect immoral, foreign, and western; within-subject), and age as predictors on the dv of acceptability ratings. Significant interactions among these variables will be further explored using simple slope analyses.
IV: religiosity, label, domain, and age
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a.	If participants respond with the same response for all items (e.g., participant only chose “okay” for all items) that participant will not be included in the final sample 
b.	For each participant, we will exclude any foreign items that participants rate as much familiar (score of 4) or higher from analyses. We will exclude any western items that participants rate as little familiar (score of 2) or lower from analyses. 
c.	If the response took too short of a time (i.e., less than 1 minute to complete the survey) that participant will be excluded

attributes.title: A meta-analytic database of randomised trials on psychotherapies for depression
attributes.description:
Background. The number of trials on psychotherapies for adult depression is very large and is quickly growing. Because of this large body of knowledge, it is important that the results of these studies are summarized and integrated in meta-analytic studies. More than a decade ago we developed a meta-analytic database of these trials, which was updated yearly through systematic literature searches. Recently, we developed a new version of this meta-analytic database, built on the systems and experience from our earlier database, but with completely new searches and improved methods. In this paper we will describe the methods and some first results of this database.
Description. We conducted systematic literature searches in bibliographical databases (PubMed, Embase, PsycINFO, Cochrane Register of Controlled Trials to identify all trials on psychotherapy for adult depression (deadline January 1st, 2019). We excluded trials on maintenance and relapse prevention, dissertations, collaborative care, and studies not published in English, German, Spanish or Dutch. After reading 21,976 records (16,701 after exclusion of duplicates), we included 661 randomized trials. We distinguished the following categories of trials: Psychotherapy versus pharmacotherapy (65 studies), combined treatment versus pharmacotherapy alone (46), combined treatment versus psychotherapy alone (29), combined treatment versus psychotherapy plus placebo (18), psychotherapy versus control (335), psychotherapy versus another therapy (109), psychotherapy for inpatients (34), unguided self-help interventions (48), comparisons of different treatment formats (38), cognitive bias modification (14) and other comparisons (99). 
Over the years we have published several dozens of meta-analyses using this databases (including its previous versions).
Conclusion. Psychotherapy for depression is definitely the best studied type of psychotherapy for any mental health problem. We hope that our database can be used as a resource for researchers who want to conduct systematic reviews and meta-analyses of subgroups of these studies.

q1.value: Preventing the onset of depressive disorders: A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials

q2.value: Pim Cuijpers, Eirini Karyotaki, Soledad Quero, Blanca Pineda, Ricardo Munoz, Sascha Y Struijs, Jazmin Llamas, Caroline Figueroa

q3.value:
Depressive disorders are highly prevalent and are associated with considerable loss of quality of life in patients and their relatives, enormous economic costs and excess mortality. Treatments can only reduce the burden of disease to a limited extent. Preventive interventions may contribute considerably to a further reduction of the disease burden of depression at a population level and prevent the suffering of patients and their families.
Only a limited number of randomized trials have focused on preventing the onset of new clinical episodes of depressive disorders, meaning that those with a disorder at baseline are excluded from participation in the trial, and that the onset of new cases is examined at follow-up (both established with a diagnostic interview). In the current meta-analysis, we will integrate the results of these randomized trials to assess whether preventive interventions can indeed prevent the onset of depressive disorders. In order to reduce heterogeneity of the interventions, we will only look at the effects of psychological interventions. 
We have published two previous meta-analyses on preventing the onset of depressive disorders, one in 2008 (Cuijpers et al., Am J Psychiatry 2008) and an update of this meta-analysis in 2014 (Van Zoonen et al., Int J Epidem 2014). The meta-analysis from 2014 included studies up to March 2012. We will now update this meta-analysis to November 2019, with broadly the same inclusion and exclusion criteria.

q4.value: We will examine whether the incidence of onset of new clinical episodes of depressive disorders can be reduced with psychological interventions. In line with previous meta-analyses we expect that these interventions are able to reduce this incidence.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This meta-analysis is an extension of the main database of trials on psychotherapies for depression (see the main website). We will select studies on subthreshold depression from the main database of studies and check if they meet inclusion criteria (meaning that participants with major depression are excluded at baseline and that incidence of onset of new clinical episodes of depressive disorders is examined at post-test). Because only studies on indicated prevention are included in the database (studies on universal and selective prevention are not), we will conduct additional searches in PubMed, PsycInfo and the Cochrane database of randomized trials.
The full search string for PubMed for these additional searches is: (("depressive disorder"[MeSH Terms] OR ("depressive"[All Fields] AND "disorder"[All Fields]) OR "depressive disorder"[All Fields] OR "depression"[All Fields] OR "depression"[MeSH  Terms]) OR depressive[All Fields]) AND (("prevention and control"[Subheading] OR ("prevention"[All Fields] AND "control"[All Fields]) OR "prevention and control"[All Fields] OR "prevention"[All Fields]) OR preventive[All Fields]) AND Randomized Controlled  Trial[ptyp]
Deadline for the searches is November 2019.
The titles and abstracts will be read by two independent researchers, and all studies that could meet inclusion according to at least one of the researchers will be retrieved as full-text. Full-text papers will also be read by two independent researchers for inclusion. Disagreements will be solved by discussion and if needed by consulting a third researcher.

q9.value: Because we will not conduct a randomized trial, but a meta-analysis, we will not randomize.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data of our meta-analytic database have been collected already, but new studies on prevention will be added to this meta-analysis. We will also retrieve additional characteristics of the included studies that have not been collected as part of the main database (see below).

q13.value: The latest meta-analysis of this field included 32 randomized trials. It is not known how many trials will be included in this update.

q14.value: Because this is a meta-analysis, we have to work with the existing, available data

q15.value: A stopping rule cannot be used in this project, because this is a meta-analytic project.

question.value: The variables that are used in this meta-analytic study include the variables that have been collected as part of our main meta-analytic project (characteristics of the participants, of the interventions, of the study). In addition to that we will collect data on the proportion of participants with a history of depression and whether the study is on universal, selective or indicated prevention.

- The main outcome is the incidence of onset of new clinical episodes of depressive disorders according to a diagnostic interview. The calculation of this incidence will follow an “intention-to-treat approach”. This means that in studies in which missing data at follow-up have been imputed, we will use these imputed data for the calculation of incidence. In studies that have not imputed missing data, we will consider those who have dropped out of the study since randomization as new incident cases. This is the most conservative approach of calculating incidence. 
- As secondary outcome we will examine completers only data (in which subjects that have dropped out of the study are excluded).
- We will calculate the Relative Risk (RR) for incidence in the intervention compared to the control conditions.
- As primary outcome we will use the RR of incidence at 12 months follow-up or the closest time point to 12 months follow-up.
- In addition, we will categorize follow-up times in the following categories: less than 12 months, 12 to 24 months, more than 24 months.
- We will also calculate the risk difference (RD) for each study and use the pooled RD to calculate the numbers-needed-to-be-treated (NNT) as 1/RD.
- In addition, we will calculate RR of acceptability (study drop-out for any reason) for the prevention compared to the control conditions.
- Other characteristics that will be collected from the studies include the characteristics of the participants, the interventions and the study that are collected as part of the main meta-analytic project.
- In addition, we will indicate the type of prevention (universal, selective, indicated) and the proportion of participants with a history of depression for each study.
- In addition to the previous meta-analyses on prevention we conducted, we will also select the studies that have identified participants through systematic screening. In these studies we will extract the number of screened people, the number of participants recruited into the trial, and after calculating the RR of reduced incidence we will calculate the numbers-needed-to-screen, indicating the number of people that have to be screened in order to prevent one depressive disorder.
- Risk of bias will be assessed (as was done in the previous meta-analyses) with four basic criteria of the ‘risk of bias’ tool of the Cochrane Collaboration: sequence generation; allocation concealment; blinding of outcome assessors; and incomplete outcome data. The assessments will be done by two reviewers independently. Disagreements will be solved by consensus, and if needed a third researcher will be consulted.
The RRs for incidence and acceptability will be calculated for each study separately and then pooled across studies with a random effects model (see below).

Because we expect considerably heterogeneity between studies, we will use a random effects model in the pooling of studies in all analyses. We will conduct subgroup analyses (across types of prevention, but also across the other characteristics of the studies) using mixed effects analyses, in which studies within subgroups are pooled with the random effects model, while tests for differences between subgroups are conducted with the fixed effects model. Multivariate and bivariate metaregression analyses, examining whether the RR is associated with characteristics of studies are conducted according to the Knapp-Hartung procedures using the restricted maximum likelihood approach. We will examine publication bias using Duval and Tweedie's trim and fill procedure and Egger's test of the intercept. Heterogeneity will be examined with I-square and its 95% CI. All analyses will be conducted in R using the “meta” and “metafor” packages

q20.value: We will not transform, center or recode data for this meta-analysis.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if differences between groups of studies are significant.

q22.value: We will only include studies that meet our inclusion criteria. We will examine outliers (studies in which the 95% CI of the RR does not overlap with the 95% CI of the RR of the pooled studies) as sensitivity analysis, but we will not exclude these from the other analyses.

q23.value: We have no missing data (studies with essential information missing are not included in the study).

q24.value:
We will conduct subgroup and meta-regression analyses with a limited number of variables, depending on the quality and number of included studies, their size and the size of the subgroups. We will examine the following variables in the subgroup and metaregression analyses (in this order of priority): risk of bias, type of prevention, target group, time to follow-up, proportion with a history of depression, type of intervention, format of the intervention, number of sessions, year of publication, country.
We will not conduct any other exploratory analyses

attributes.title: Are introspective confidence judgments reflected in the motor dynamics of response selection?

q1.value: "Are introspective confidence judgments reflected in the motor dynamics of response selection?"

q3.value: This mouse-tracking study is based on and is a conceptual replication of the (first experiment of the) 2007 study by Dale, Kehoe and Spivey on atypical classification, with the addition of self-reported confidence ratings after each trial: Participants are shown the name of an animal (e.g.: “cat” or “whale”) along with two taxonomic classes (e.g.: “mammal” and “fish”) and their task is to select the correct category for the animal. Some animals are regarded to be typical for their respective class (e.g.: “cat” for “mammal”) while others are regarded atypical since they also share similarities with the distractor class (e.g.: “whale”). The aim is to investigate whether there is any covariance between the participants’ self-reported confidence levels and the manual movement dynamics of response selection, such as response time and curvature of mouse trajectories.

q4.value:
It is expected to replicate the general trends of results from the original study, namely that there are “significant differences” between the trajectories found for typical and atypical trials. This should hold for both for temporal and spatial analyses.

Classification of typical exemplars should covary with a higher mean of confidence ratings than for atypical exemplars. 
If the classification of typical exemplars covaries a higher mean of confidence ratings, then it also should covary with…
- a higher ratio of correct answers than for atypical exemplars.
- a lower mean of response times (RT).
- an earlier occurrence of the movement’s maximum velocity (vel_max_time).
- a decreased mean curvature of the trajectory, as measured by the trajectories’ area under the curve (AUC), which is the geometric area between the observed, actual trajectory and the direct path between the start and end coordinates.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Repeated-measures within-subject design with 1 factor (typicality) and 2 levels (typical, atypical).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited among fellow students of Osnabrück University, Germany. They will be offered course credit (= experimental subject hours) for their participation and must fulfil the following requirements:
- German native speakers
- Normal or corrected-to-normal vision

q13.value: The target sample size is 15 participants.

q14.value:
Only limited resources are available since the study is conducted by a single person as her bachelor’s thesis. Further, while the study is not strictly of exploratory nature, it still could potentially function as a pilot study: So far, it has not been researched whether there is a covariance between self-reported confidence levels and motor dynamics of response selection. Therefore, testing with a small sample size if there is such an effect could be used to check if it would be sensible further investigating this relation on a larger scale.
Lastly, the plan is only to apply descriptive statistics, rather than draw inferences, so a sample size of 15 should deliver enough data points.

question.value: Following the original study, the manipulated variable is the typicality of exemplars. The two levels of this categorical variable are "typical" and "atypical".

Measured will be:

- Percentage of correct trials
- Response times in ms
- Confidence ratings (on a scale of 1-6, 1 being “unsure” and 6 being “very sure”)
- Mouse trajectories (= x- & y-coordinates in z time steps); derived from which are:
-- Vel_max_time
-- AUC

From that will be calculated:

- Means and standard deviations of RT, vel_max_time, AUC and confidence ratings
- Covariances and Correlations between mean confidence ratings and percentage of correct trials, RTs, vel_max_time, AUC

The plan is only to apply descriptive statistics, rather than draw inferences, so no statistical models in the classical sense will be applied. 

Pre-Processing

1)	Calculate percentage of correct answers per condition
2)	Filter out practice trials and incorrect trials
3)	Re-mapping trajectories to one side of the coordinate system 
4)	Shift trajectories so that all have an aligned starting position 
5)	Apply time-normalisation to aggregate trajectories and compare them statistically

Analyses

6)	Visual inspection of aggregate time-normalized trajectories
7)	Calculate mean and standard deviation for each participant and per condition
i.	Response time (RT)
ii.	Time at which maximum velocity occurred (first) (vel_max_time)
iii.	Curvature (AUC)
iv.	Confidence
8)	Calculate covariance and correlation of means between
i.	Confidence ratings and number of correct answers
ii.	Confidence ratings and RTs
iii.	Confidence ratings and vel_max_time
iv.	Confidence ratings and AUC

registration_responses.q1: "Are introspective confidence judgments reflected in the motor dynamics of response selection?"
registration_responses.q3: This mouse-tracking study is based on and is a conceptual replication of the (first experiment of the) 2007 study by Dale, Kehoe and Spivey on atypical classification, with the addition of self-reported confidence ratings after each trial: Participants are shown the name of an animal (e.g.: “cat” or “whale”) along with two taxonomic classes (e.g.: “mammal” and “fish”) and their task is to select the correct category for the animal. Some animals are regarded to be typical for their respective class (e.g.: “cat” for “mammal”) while others are regarded atypical since they also share similarities with the distractor class (e.g.: “whale”). The aim is to investigate whether there is any covariance between the participants’ self-reported confidence levels and the manual movement dynamics of response selection, such as response time and curvature of mouse trajectories.
registration_responses.q4:
It is expected to replicate the general trends of results from the original study, namely that there are “significant differences” between the trajectories found for typical and atypical trials. This should hold for both for temporal and spatial analyses.

Classification of typical exemplars should covary with a higher mean of confidence ratings than for atypical exemplars. 
If the classification of typical exemplars covaries a higher mean of confidence ratings, then it also should covary with…
- a higher ratio of correct answers than for atypical exemplars.
- a lower mean of response times (RT).
- an earlier occurrence of the movement’s maximum velocity (vel_max_time).
- a decreased mean curvature of the trajectory, as measured by the trajectories’ area under the curve (AUC), which is the geometric area between the observed, actual trajectory and the direct path between the start and end coordinates.

dataCollectionDates.value: Observations are planned between January 2020 and July 2020. If sample has not been reached until July 2020, we will continue observation between September 2020 and December 2020. All observations will be finished at the latest on December 2020.

question2a.value: SES (low-SES, middle-SES, and high-SES), assessed by parental occupation will be the between-participants IV. SES ranking will be determined by the highest level of occupation held by either parent. For example, if the mother is a physician and the father a manual worker, the student will be assigned to the high SES group. Low-SES group will include children of manual and administrative workers, other blue-collar workers (employees, artisans, farmers, etc.), and unemployed persons. Middle-SES group will include children whose parents have intermediate occupations as technicians, nurses, educators, intermediate civil servant or military personnel. High-SES group will include children of managers, engineers, researchers and professors, as well as professional managerial elite (e.g., lawyers, architects, doctors, etc.).

question2b.value:
A coding scheme have been established with The Noldus Observer XT software (Version 14.2, 2018). For each child, we will code the duration and number of occurrences of speaking as an indicator of oral participation. More specifically, the coding scheme includes the following behaviors: “speak” and “non speak”. The former includes four modifiers: (1) “speak after being questioned by the teacher”; (2) “speak without being questioned by the teacher”; (3) “speak by interrupting another child”; (4) “speak by interrupting the teacher”. These modifiers will be regrouped in two meta-categories for the analyses: “speak after being questioned” (i.e., modifier 1) and “speak without being questioned”, which regroups modifiers (2), (3) and (4).
Thus, we will have 4 variables: (1) number of time children speak after being questioned, (2) number of times children speak without being questioned, (3) speaking time after being questioned and (4) speaking time without being questioned.

question3b.value: In an exploratory way, the three years of preschool will be used as a moderator.

question10b.value:
First, we will select classrooms with only one age-level, that is, with children born the same year. Second, we will select classrooms with SES diversity. To pre-select the school according to these criteria, we will benefit from the help of academic authorities. To maximize acceptance rate, we will organize meetings in the schools (with the directors and the teachers) to present the project in detail. This will familiarize the directors and the teachers with the project and they will thus be able to answer parents’ questions and respond to potential concerns. 
Procedure and material
The study will consist in a series of observations in French preschools. Preschool days are very structured: The children alternate between free play times, collective greeting times or circle times, and educational activities in small groups. Typically, after an initial free play time, the preschool day begins with a circle time that consists of all children sitting in a circle, and the teacher giving a semi-structured lesson. These circle times exist in all French preschools and take place 2-4 times a day. They vary in content and style, including discussing the weather, counting the number of boys and girls in the circle, reading a book, talking about personal experiences or singing a song. In order to make comparison between classrooms possible, we will limit the observations to these circle times.
All videos will be recorded and time coded with Noldus Media Recorder (version 2.5, 2013). 6 to 8 collective circle times will be recorded by classroom. For greeting times (i.e., collective circle time), 6 cameras linked to the recording device (Noldus Media Recorder) will be installed in the “circle area” (i.e., the place in the classroom where circle times take place) before the children arrived in the classroom the morning. For each observation, a research assistant will start the recording device before leaving the classroom in order to avoid interference with the course of the session. After that, the observations will be coded and the data analyzed, a meeting with the teachers involved in the study will be organized in order to debrief them and to present them the main results. 
Data Coding
Following the observation sessions, the obtained video-footage will be uploaded onto multiple secure hard-drives. Next, the video-footage of the four cameras will be synchronized and paired together using Noldus Observer XT software (Version 14.2, 2018). 
Coding children and teacher’s behaviors. A coding scheme have been established before data collection with The Noldus Observer XT software (Version 14.2, 2018). For each child, we will code the duration and number of occurrences of speaking as an indicator of oral participation. More specifically, the coding scheme includes the following behaviors: “speak” and “non speak”. The former includes four modifiers: (1) “speak after being questioned by the teacher”; (2) “speak without being questioned by the teacher”; (3) “speak by interrupting another child”; (4) “speak by interrupting the teacher”. These modifiers will be regrouped in two meta-categories for the analyses: “speak after being questioned” (i.e., modifier 1) and “speak without being questioned”, which regroups modifiers (2), (3) and (4). The behavior “speak” will not be coded when more than 3 children are speaking at the same time. All observations will be double coded by two independent coders. Intraclass coefficient correlation (ICC) will be used to analyze the inter-observer reliability. Based on Cicchetti’s (1964) classification, an ICC greater or equal to .60 reflects a good reliability between the two coders. We thus aim to reach ICC of at least .60 for the double coded observations. To ensure the anonymity of the collected data (coded behaviors, sex, date of birth and occupation of parents), the teacher will attribute a random numeric code to each child. This code will be used to match children’s behaviors and administrative records.
Coding SES. In social sciences, and in psychology in particular, different indicators are used to measure SES. The three main indicators are income, level of education and type of occupation (Kraus & Stephens, 2012; Oakes & Rossi, 2003). In this study, SES will be assessed according to parental occupations (Goudeau & Croizet, 2017) as it is the only indicator available from French school authorities. This variable has been shown to be a good proxy for overall SES (Oakes & Rossi, 2003; Goudeau, Autin, & Croizet, 2017). SES ranking will be determined by the highest level of occupation held by either parent. For example, if the mother is a physician and the father a manual worker, the student will be assigned to the high SES group. Low-SES group will include children of manual and administrative workers, other blue-collar workers (employees, artisans, farmers, etc.), and unemployed persons. Middle-SES group will include children whose parents have intermediate occupations as technicians, nurses, educators, intermediate civil servant or military personnel. High-SES group will include children of managers, engineers, researchers and professors, as well as professional managerial elite (e.g., lawyers, architects, doctors, etc.).

question4b.value: We have defined some criteria of selection before contacting schools. First, we will select classrooms with only one age-level, that is, with children born the same year. Indeed, classrooms can sometimes include two age-levels (e.g., “Petite-Section/Moyenne-Section”) and we want to avoid having both age and SES variations in the same classroom. Second, we will select classrooms with SES diversity. To pre-select the school according to these criteria, we will benefit from the help of academic authorities. Finally, we will not observe classrooms where more than three children would not be allowed by their parents to be filmed because that implies that we will have a biased sample.

question5b.value: All videos will be recorded and time coded with Noldus Media Recorder (version 2.5, 2013). 6 to 8 collective greeting times (i.e., circle times) will be recorded by classroom. For collective circle time, 6 cameras linked to the recording device (Noldus Media Recorder) will be installed in the “circle area” (i.e., the place in the classroom where circle times take place) before the children arrived in the classroom the morning. For each observation, a research assistant will start the recording device before leaving the classroom in order to avoid interference with the course of the session. After that, the observations will be coded by research assistants.

question6b.value: Participants will be preschoolers from 3 sections: “Petite Section” (3 to 4 years old), “Moyenne Section” (4 to 5 years old), “Grande Section” (5 to 6 years old). Because of constraints to access a large number of schools,  our sample is defined a priori. We will have access to 21 classrooms of about 25 students (N = 525). We thus computed a sensitivity analysis (using G*Power software version 3.1) to estimate which effect size we would detect with 95% power for 1) the effect of SES (coded with two Helmert contrasts; model with 2 predictors) and 2) the interaction between SES and year (coded with two orthogonal contrasts; model with 8 predictors, see below for more details). The sensitivity analysis shows that a sample of 525 preschoolers would allow to detect a small to medium effect size for the effect of SES (d = 0.34) as well as for the interaction between SES and year (d = 0.42 ).

question7b.value: Data collection will stop when we will reach the desire sample size, namely 525 children.

We plan to exclude children with disabilities (i.e., any troubles that necessitate the presence of an educational assistance) and students that arrived in the country in the two years preceding data collection.
