question1a.value:
Based on a pilot study (N = 100), we will test the 4 following predictions:
(H1) low-SES children are less likely to be questioned by the teacher than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children).
(H2) low-SES children speak for a shorter time -“hold the floor”- after being questioned by the teacher than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children). 
(H3) low-SES children are less likely to “take the floor” (i.e., speak without being asked to or interrupt other children or the teacher) than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children).
(H4) low-SES children speak for a shorter time after “taking the floor” than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children). 

Besides these hypotheses referring to SES, we will run two explanatory sets of analyses; one concerning the grade and one concerning gender. 

First, we will analyze the influence of gender on oral participation and its interaction with SES. The pilot study (N = 100) showed that girls speak less than boys. We will address these exploratory research questions:
(H5) Are girls are less likely to be questioned by the teacher than boys?
(H6) Do girls speak for a shorter time -“hold the floor”- after being questioned by the teacher than boys. 
(H7) Are girls are less likely to “take the floor” (i.e., speak without being asked to or interrupt other children or the teacher) than boys.
(H8) Do girls speak for a shorter time after “taking the floor” than boys. 
(H9) We will also test whether the SES moderates those differences between boys and girls. 

Second, our transversal design across the three years of preschool will allow us to examine how inequalities in oral participation change or remain the same from the beginning to the end of preschool. We will address these exploratory research questions: 
(H10) Do the differences related to SES in the number of times children are questioned by the teacher remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?
(H11) Do the differences related to SES in the time children speak -“hold the floor”- after being questioned by the teacher remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?
(H12) Do the differences related to SES in the number of times children “take the floor” (i.e., speak without being asked to or interrupt other children or the teacher) remain constant, are attenuated or amplified? 
(H13) Do the differences related to SES in the time children speak after “taking the floor” remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?

question3a.value: We do not manipulate any variable, we will use parental occupations to assess SES, as it is the only indicator available from French school authorities. This variable has been shown to be a good proxy for overall SES (Goudeau, Autin, & Croizet, 2017).

question5a.value:
In many countries, socioeconomic status (SES), which can be captured by education, income, and/or occupational status, has a significant influence on academic achievement: the lower a student’s SES, the more likely they are to experience difficulties and to drop out of school before attending university (OCDE, 2016). This influence of SES is observed very early during development: Compared to low-SES children, middle- and high-SES children have higher verbal skills at the age of 2 (Grobon, Panico, & Solaz, 2019), and they possess more knowledge of the sounds and names of letters, as well as a higher level of familiarity with books at the age of 4 (Bowey, 1995; Lonigan, Burgess, Anthony, & Barker, 1998; Sublet & Prêteur, 1988). In many countries, despite important differences in the availability of early childhood education systems, preschool is designed to reduce these initial inequalities by providing low-SES children with greater familiarity and readiness in speaking, pre-reading and counting. However, existing studies do not fully support that preschool is a great equalizer as initial disparities in education are still existent at the beginning of first grade (Colmant, Jeantheau, & Murat, 2002; Lee & Burkam, 2002; Maurin, 2007; Rocher, 2015). The first objective of this study is to examine why preschool settings fail to level initial academic disparities related to SES backgrounds. Our hypothesis is that preschool settings could unintentionally not allowing an equal oral participation of children from different SES backgrounds. Moreover, the fact that inequalities are still persistent in first grade do not inform us regarding their evolution during preschool: are they attenuated, do they remain constant, or are they amplified? As existing studies stay silent regarding this evolution during preschool, our second objective is to investigate how inequalities evolve from the beginning to the end of preschool. 
Studies conducted in France and in the United States reveal that early and regular attendance is beneficial for achievement –especially for low-SES children– as it provides an advantage at school entry (e.g., alphabet recognition, counting, and prewriting and reading skills; Huang, 2017). However, these types of advantages are not systematic and mostly depend on the quality of the preschool programs (Lipsey, Farran, & Durkin, 2018). Moreover, there is substantial evidence that despite these benefits, attending preschool does not level the playing field as low-SES children enter first grade still lagging behind middle- and high-SES children in terms of speaking, reading, writing as well as counting skills (Colmant, Jeantheau, & Murat, 2002; Lee & Burkam, 2002; Maurin, 2007; Rocher, 2015). Furthering our understanding of the construction of inequalities at the preschool level is a major issue, as these initial inequalities lay the groundwork for subsequent differences throughout students’ progression in the educational system. 
The persistent relationship between SES and academic achievement can be explained by structural factors such as poverty, neighborhood or home environment, which have a direct impact on academic skills (American Psychological Association. Task Force on Socioeconomic Status, 2007; Duncan & Brooks-Gunn, 1997). However, a growing body of evidence has also highlighted the role played by classroom contexts in the achievement gap between middle- high-SES students and low-SES students (Croizet, Goudeau, Marot, & Millet, 2017). Understanding how academic contexts can play a role in the achievement gap related to SES backgrounds requires considering that academic settings and practices are not neutral. Indeed, classrooms settings are inherently saturated with cultural norms (e.g., language use, school knowledge or ways of being) that are closer to the cultural dispositions shaped in middle- and high-SES families than those developed in low-SES families (Bernstein, 1975; Bourdieu & Passeron, 1990; Lareau, 2003; Stephens, Markus, & Fryberg, 2012; Stephens, Markus, & Phillips, 2014). Recent research has documented that the cultural mismatch between academic norms and cultural dispositions developed through family socialization undermines low-SES students’ achievement (Goudeau & Croizet, 2017; Stephens, Fryberg, Markus, Johnson, & Covarrubias, 2012).
The cultural mismatch between the home and school resides in two core dimensions: First, academic settings tend to promote and reward independence as the cultural standard for how to be a good student (Stephens, Fryberg et al., 2012). For example, teachers expect students to develop and to use their voice to express their own opinions and interests, to share their personal experience and make their own choices. This independent way of being which orients students to their own thoughts, feelings and actions is closer to middle- and high-SES family’s socialization practices that invite children to put forward their interests, preferences and opinions in various activities of everyday life than to low-SES family’s socialization practices (Lareau, 2003; Kusserow, 2004; Miller & Cho, 2018; Miller, Cho & Bracey, 2005; Schieffelin & Ochs, 1986). At the university level, research has documented that low-SES students’ experience of cultural mismatch with independent norms can undermine academic performance (Stephens, Fryberg et al., 2012). 
Second, academic contexts value some forms of academic knowledge and skills that are closer to the cultural dispositions shaped in middle- and high-SES contexts than those shaped in low-SES contexts (Lareau, 2003; Goudeau & Croizet, 2017; Lahire, 2019). For instance, middle- and high-SES parents are more likely than low-SES parents to engage in cultural practices that develop academic readiness, such as playing educational games at home, reading stories to children or going to museums and libraries. Experiments with 5th and 6th graders have shown that having less familiarity with academic tasks led low-SES children to experience social comparisons that disrupt their achievement (Goudeau & Croizet, 2017). While research has examined how the experience of cultural mismatch can be detrimental for achievement – from primary school to university– it has yet to focus on the mechanisms through which preschools may unintentionally amplify —instead of reduce— academic disparities related to SES and thus undermine the future achievement of low-SES students.
Some qualitative observations offer initial insight into how preschool may unintentionally amplify academic disparities. In preschool, classroom settings accord an important role to children’s participation and a great deal of attention is paid to their verbalization (Millet & Croizet, 2016; Streib, 2011). During circle time or classroom meetings, teachers expect children to share their personal experiences (e.g., “what did you do this weekend?”) and to express their opinion and interests. Nevertheless, qualitative observations in particular preschools suggest that low-SES children are less likely than middle- and high-SES children to engage in such valued behaviors (e.g., participating in the collective exchanges and verbalizing one’s experience in front of the class ; Millet & Croizet, 2016; Montmasson-Michel, 2018; Streib, 2011). Other qualitative observations in preschool have also revealed that teachers tend to favor middle- and high-SES children’s participation as they comply with their expectations (Florin, Braun-Lamesch & Bramaud du Boucheron, 1985). Although these observations offer initial insights, they rely on qualitative observations and involve small sample of children. 
This research aims at complementing these observations by assessing the generalizability of these results with quantitative methodology. Using quantitative methodology to examine oral participation in real classroom settings will provide corroborative evidence regarding the mechanisms that underlie why preschools can unintentionally fail to level initial disparities related to SES.

IV. SES will be coded with two Helmert contrasts as predictors (Brauer & McClelland, 2005), the first one comparing low-SES children (coded -2/3) to both middle-SES and high-SES children (coded +1/3) and the second one comparing middle-SES children (coded -0.5) to high-SES children (coded +0.5; low-SES being coded 0).

DV. number of time children speak after being questioned.

question2c.value: The analyses will be performed using the software program R (Version 3.4.3). Data will be analyzed with a generalized linear model with classroom-period fixed-effects using packages “MASS” (Venables & Ripley, 2002) and “lme4” (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). Observations are nested in periods of observation and classrooms therefore violating the assumption of independence of residuals. In such case, multi-level models can be used but they produce biased estimates with low numbers of higher-level units (Maas & Hox, 2005; Sommet & Morselli, 2017). We will perform fixed-effects models that remove all classroom-period variations and estimate the within classroom-period effects of SES on oral participation. To address heteroscedasticity, we will compute robust standard errors.

Data will be analyzed with a generalized linear model with classroom-period fixed-effects using packages “MASS” (Venables & Ripley, 2002) and “lme4” (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). Observations are nested in periods of observation and classrooms therefore violating the assumption of independence of residuals. In such case, multi-level models can be used but they produce biased estimates with low numbers of higher-level units (Maas & Hox, 2005; Sommet & Morselli, 2017). We will perform fixed-effects models that remove all classroom-period variations and estimate the within classroom-period effects of SES on oral participation. To address heteroscedasticity, we will compute robust standard errors.

IV. SES will be coded with two Helmert contrasts as predictors (Brauer & McClelland, 2005), the first one comparing low-SES children (coded -2/3) to both middle-SES and high-SES children (coded +1/3) and the second one comparing middle-SES children (coded -0.5) to high-SES children (coded +0.5; low-SES being coded 0). Gender will be coded with one contrast that will allow us to compare oral participation of girls (coded -0.5) and boys (coded +0.5).  These contrasts will allow us to analyze the gender effect and the possible interaction between gender and SES by computing interactions between the two coded contrasts for SES (i.e., low-SES vs. [middle and high-SES] and middle-SES vs. high-SES). Concerning our explanatory analysis, year will be coded with two orthogonal contrasts, the first one comparing first year of preschool (coded -0.5) to third year of preschool (coded +0.5; second year coded 0) and the second one comparing second year (coded +2/3) to both first and third year (coded -1/3). These contrasts will allow us to analyze the possible attenuation and amplification of SES differences in oral participation throughout preschool by computing interactions between the two coded contrasts for SES (i.e., low-SES vs. [middle and high-SES] and middle-SES vs. high-SES) and the two orthogonal contrasts for year. Linear pattern of attenuation or amplification would be supported by a significant interaction with the first orthogonal contrast (i.e., first year vs. third year) and a non-significant interaction with the second orthogonal contrast (i.e., second year vs. [first-year and third-year]).

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
Based on a pilot study (N = 100), we will test the 4 following predictions:
(H1) low-SES children are less likely to be questioned by the teacher than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children).
(H2) low-SES children speak for a shorter time -“hold the floor”- after being questioned by the teacher than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children). 
(H3) low-SES children are less likely to “take the floor” (i.e., speak without being asked to or interrupt other children or the teacher) than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children).
(H4) low-SES children speak for a shorter time after “taking the floor” than middle- and high-SES children (we expect no difference between middle-SES children and high-SES children). 

Besides these hypotheses referring to SES, we will run two explanatory sets of analyses; one concerning the grade and one concerning gender. 

First, we will analyze the influence of gender on oral participation and its interaction with SES. The pilot study (N = 100) showed that girls speak less than boys. We will address these exploratory research questions:
(H5) Are girls are less likely to be questioned by the teacher than boys?
(H6) Do girls speak for a shorter time -“hold the floor”- after being questioned by the teacher than boys. 
(H7) Are girls are less likely to “take the floor” (i.e., speak without being asked to or interrupt other children or the teacher) than boys.
(H8) Do girls speak for a shorter time after “taking the floor” than boys. 
(H9) We will also test whether the SES moderates those differences between boys and girls. 

Second, our transversal design across the three years of preschool will allow us to examine how inequalities in oral participation change or remain the same from the beginning to the end of preschool. We will address these exploratory research questions: 
(H10) Do the differences related to SES in the number of times children are questioned by the teacher remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?
(H11) Do the differences related to SES in the time children speak -“hold the floor”- after being questioned by the teacher remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?
(H12) Do the differences related to SES in the number of times children “take the floor” (i.e., speak without being asked to or interrupt other children or the teacher) remain constant, are attenuated or amplified? 
(H13) Do the differences related to SES in the time children speak after “taking the floor” remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: We do not manipulate any variable, we will use parental occupations to assess SES, as it is the only indicator available from French school authorities. This variable has been shown to be a good proxy for overall SES (Goudeau, Autin, & Croizet, 2017).
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
In many countries, socioeconomic status (SES), which can be captured by education, income, and/or occupational status, has a significant influence on academic achievement: the lower a student’s SES, the more likely they are to experience difficulties and to drop out of school before attending university (OCDE, 2016). This influence of SES is observed very early during development: Compared to low-SES children, middle- and high-SES children have higher verbal skills at the age of 2 (Grobon, Panico, & Solaz, 2019), and they possess more knowledge of the sounds and names of letters, as well as a higher level of familiarity with books at the age of 4 (Bowey, 1995; Lonigan, Burgess, Anthony, & Barker, 1998; Sublet & Prêteur, 1988). In many countries, despite important differences in the availability of early childhood education systems, preschool is designed to reduce these initial inequalities by providing low-SES children with greater familiarity and readiness in speaking, pre-reading and counting. However, existing studies do not fully support that preschool is a great equalizer as initial disparities in education are still existent at the beginning of first grade (Colmant, Jeantheau, & Murat, 2002; Lee & Burkam, 2002; Maurin, 2007; Rocher, 2015). The first objective of this study is to examine why preschool settings fail to level initial academic disparities related to SES backgrounds. Our hypothesis is that preschool settings could unintentionally not allowing an equal oral participation of children from different SES backgrounds. Moreover, the fact that inequalities are still persistent in first grade do not inform us regarding their evolution during preschool: are they attenuated, do they remain constant, or are they amplified? As existing studies stay silent regarding this evolution during preschool, our second objective is to investigate how inequalities evolve from the beginning to the end of preschool. 
Studies conducted in France and in the United States reveal that early and regular attendance is beneficial for achievement –especially for low-SES children– as it provides an advantage at school entry (e.g., alphabet recognition, counting, and prewriting and reading skills; Huang, 2017). However, these types of advantages are not systematic and mostly depend on the quality of the preschool programs (Lipsey, Farran, & Durkin, 2018). Moreover, there is substantial evidence that despite these benefits, attending preschool does not level the playing field as low-SES children enter first grade still lagging behind middle- and high-SES children in terms of speaking, reading, writing as well as counting skills (Colmant, Jeantheau, & Murat, 2002; Lee & Burkam, 2002; Maurin, 2007; Rocher, 2015). Furthering our understanding of the construction of inequalities at the preschool level is a major issue, as these initial inequalities lay the groundwork for subsequent differences throughout students’ progression in the educational system. 
The persistent relationship between SES and academic achievement can be explained by structural factors such as poverty, neighborhood or home environment, which have a direct impact on academic skills (American Psychological Association. Task Force on Socioeconomic Status, 2007; Duncan & Brooks-Gunn, 1997). However, a growing body of evidence has also highlighted the role played by classroom contexts in the achievement gap between middle- high-SES students and low-SES students (Croizet, Goudeau, Marot, & Millet, 2017). Understanding how academic contexts can play a role in the achievement gap related to SES backgrounds requires considering that academic settings and practices are not neutral. Indeed, classrooms settings are inherently saturated with cultural norms (e.g., language use, school knowledge or ways of being) that are closer to the cultural dispositions shaped in middle- and high-SES families than those developed in low-SES families (Bernstein, 1975; Bourdieu & Passeron, 1990; Lareau, 2003; Stephens, Markus, & Fryberg, 2012; Stephens, Markus, & Phillips, 2014). Recent research has documented that the cultural mismatch between academic norms and cultural dispositions developed through family socialization undermines low-SES students’ achievement (Goudeau & Croizet, 2017; Stephens, Fryberg, Markus, Johnson, & Covarrubias, 2012).
The cultural mismatch between the home and school resides in two core dimensions: First, academic settings tend to promote and reward independence as the cultural standard for how to be a good student (Stephens, Fryberg et al., 2012). For example, teachers expect students to develop and to use their voice to express their own opinions and interests, to share their personal experience and make their own choices. This independent way of being which orients students to their own thoughts, feelings and actions is closer to middle- and high-SES family’s socialization practices that invite children to put forward their interests, preferences and opinions in various activities of everyday life than to low-SES family’s socialization practices (Lareau, 2003; Kusserow, 2004; Miller & Cho, 2018; Miller, Cho & Bracey, 2005; Schieffelin & Ochs, 1986). At the university level, research has documented that low-SES students’ experience of cultural mismatch with independent norms can undermine academic performance (Stephens, Fryberg et al., 2012). 
Second, academic contexts value some forms of academic knowledge and skills that are closer to the cultural dispositions shaped in middle- and high-SES contexts than those shaped in low-SES contexts (Lareau, 2003; Goudeau & Croizet, 2017; Lahire, 2019). For instance, middle- and high-SES parents are more likely than low-SES parents to engage in cultural practices that develop academic readiness, such as playing educational games at home, reading stories to children or going to museums and libraries. Experiments with 5th and 6th graders have shown that having less familiarity with academic tasks led low-SES children to experience social comparisons that disrupt their achievement (Goudeau & Croizet, 2017). While research has examined how the experience of cultural mismatch can be detrimental for achievement – from primary school to university– it has yet to focus on the mechanisms through which preschools may unintentionally amplify —instead of reduce— academic disparities related to SES and thus undermine the future achievement of low-SES students.
Some qualitative observations offer initial insight into how preschool may unintentionally amplify academic disparities. In preschool, classroom settings accord an important role to children’s participation and a great deal of attention is paid to their verbalization (Millet & Croizet, 2016; Streib, 2011). During circle time or classroom meetings, teachers expect children to share their personal experiences (e.g., “what did you do this weekend?”) and to express their opinion and interests. Nevertheless, qualitative observations in particular preschools suggest that low-SES children are less likely than middle- and high-SES children to engage in such valued behaviors (e.g., participating in the collective exchanges and verbalizing one’s experience in front of the class ; Millet & Croizet, 2016; Montmasson-Michel, 2018; Streib, 2011). Other qualitative observations in preschool have also revealed that teachers tend to favor middle- and high-SES children’s participation as they comply with their expectations (Florin, Braun-Lamesch & Bramaud du Boucheron, 1985). Although these observations offer initial insights, they rely on qualitative observations and involve small sample of children. 
This research aims at complementing these observations by assessing the generalizability of these results with quantitative methodology. Using quantitative methodology to examine oral participation in real classroom settings will provide corroborative evidence regarding the mechanisms that underlie why preschools can unintentionally fail to level initial disparities related to SES.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a: SES (low-SES, middle-SES, and high-SES), assessed by parental occupation will be the between-participants IV. SES ranking will be determined by the highest level of occupation held by either parent. For example, if the mother is a physician and the father a manual worker, the student will be assigned to the high SES group. Low-SES group will include children of manual and administrative workers, other blue-collar workers (employees, artisans, farmers, etc.), and unemployed persons. Middle-SES group will include children whose parents have intermediate occupations as technicians, nurses, educators, intermediate civil servant or military personnel. High-SES group will include children of managers, engineers, researchers and professors, as well as professional managerial elite (e.g., lawyers, architects, doctors, etc.).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
A coding scheme have been established with The Noldus Observer XT software (Version 14.2, 2018). For each child, we will code the duration and number of occurrences of speaking as an indicator of oral participation. More specifically, the coding scheme includes the following behaviors: “speak” and “non speak”. The former includes four modifiers: (1) “speak after being questioned by the teacher”; (2) “speak without being questioned by the teacher”; (3) “speak by interrupting another child”; (4) “speak by interrupting the teacher”. These modifiers will be regrouped in two meta-categories for the analyses: “speak after being questioned” (i.e., modifier 1) and “speak without being questioned”, which regroups modifiers (2), (3) and (4).
Thus, we will have 4 variables: (1) number of time children speak after being questioned, (2) number of times children speak without being questioned, (3) speaking time after being questioned and (4) speaking time without being questioned.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: In an exploratory way, the three years of preschool will be used as a moderator.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
First, we will select classrooms with only one age-level, that is, with children born the same year. Second, we will select classrooms with SES diversity. To pre-select the school according to these criteria, we will benefit from the help of academic authorities. To maximize acceptance rate, we will organize meetings in the schools (with the directors and the teachers) to present the project in detail. This will familiarize the directors and the teachers with the project and they will thus be able to answer parents’ questions and respond to potential concerns. 
Procedure and material
The study will consist in a series of observations in French preschools. Preschool days are very structured: The children alternate between free play times, collective greeting times or circle times, and educational activities in small groups. Typically, after an initial free play time, the preschool day begins with a circle time that consists of all children sitting in a circle, and the teacher giving a semi-structured lesson. These circle times exist in all French preschools and take place 2-4 times a day. They vary in content and style, including discussing the weather, counting the number of boys and girls in the circle, reading a book, talking about personal experiences or singing a song. In order to make comparison between classrooms possible, we will limit the observations to these circle times.
All videos will be recorded and time coded with Noldus Media Recorder (version 2.5, 2013). 6 to 8 collective circle times will be recorded by classroom. For greeting times (i.e., collective circle time), 6 cameras linked to the recording device (Noldus Media Recorder) will be installed in the “circle area” (i.e., the place in the classroom where circle times take place) before the children arrived in the classroom the morning. For each observation, a research assistant will start the recording device before leaving the classroom in order to avoid interference with the course of the session. After that, the observations will be coded and the data analyzed, a meeting with the teachers involved in the study will be organized in order to debrief them and to present them the main results. 
Data Coding
Following the observation sessions, the obtained video-footage will be uploaded onto multiple secure hard-drives. Next, the video-footage of the four cameras will be synchronized and paired together using Noldus Observer XT software (Version 14.2, 2018). 
Coding children and teacher’s behaviors. A coding scheme have been established before data collection with The Noldus Observer XT software (Version 14.2, 2018). For each child, we will code the duration and number of occurrences of speaking as an indicator of oral participation. More specifically, the coding scheme includes the following behaviors: “speak” and “non speak”. The former includes four modifiers: (1) “speak after being questioned by the teacher”; (2) “speak without being questioned by the teacher”; (3) “speak by interrupting another child”; (4) “speak by interrupting the teacher”. These modifiers will be regrouped in two meta-categories for the analyses: “speak after being questioned” (i.e., modifier 1) and “speak without being questioned”, which regroups modifiers (2), (3) and (4). The behavior “speak” will not be coded when more than 3 children are speaking at the same time. All observations will be double coded by two independent coders. Intraclass coefficient correlation (ICC) will be used to analyze the inter-observer reliability. Based on Cicchetti’s (1964) classification, an ICC greater or equal to .60 reflects a good reliability between the two coders. We thus aim to reach ICC of at least .60 for the double coded observations. To ensure the anonymity of the collected data (coded behaviors, sex, date of birth and occupation of parents), the teacher will attribute a random numeric code to each child. This code will be used to match children’s behaviors and administrative records.
Coding SES. In social sciences, and in psychology in particular, different indicators are used to measure SES. The three main indicators are income, level of education and type of occupation (Kraus & Stephens, 2012; Oakes & Rossi, 2003). In this study, SES will be assessed according to parental occupations (Goudeau & Croizet, 2017) as it is the only indicator available from French school authorities. This variable has been shown to be a good proxy for overall SES (Oakes & Rossi, 2003; Goudeau, Autin, & Croizet, 2017). SES ranking will be determined by the highest level of occupation held by either parent. For example, if the mother is a physician and the father a manual worker, the student will be assigned to the high SES group. Low-SES group will include children of manual and administrative workers, other blue-collar workers (employees, artisans, farmers, etc.), and unemployed persons. Middle-SES group will include children whose parents have intermediate occupations as technicians, nurses, educators, intermediate civil servant or military personnel. High-SES group will include children of managers, engineers, researchers and professors, as well as professional managerial elite (e.g., lawyers, architects, doctors, etc.).

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: We have defined some criteria of selection before contacting schools. First, we will select classrooms with only one age-level, that is, with children born the same year. Indeed, classrooms can sometimes include two age-levels (e.g., “Petite-Section/Moyenne-Section”) and we want to avoid having both age and SES variations in the same classroom. Second, we will select classrooms with SES diversity. To pre-select the school according to these criteria, we will benefit from the help of academic authorities. Finally, we will not observe classrooms where more than three children would not be allowed by their parents to be filmed because that implies that we will have a biased sample.

All videos will be recorded and time coded with Noldus Media Recorder (version 2.5, 2013). 6 to 8 collective greeting times (i.e., circle times) will be recorded by classroom. For collective circle time, 6 cameras linked to the recording device (Noldus Media Recorder) will be installed in the “circle area” (i.e., the place in the classroom where circle times take place) before the children arrived in the classroom the morning. For each observation, a research assistant will start the recording device before leaving the classroom in order to avoid interference with the course of the session. After that, the observations will be coded by research assistants.

Participants will be preschoolers from 3 sections: “Petite Section” (3 to 4 years old), “Moyenne Section” (4 to 5 years old), “Grande Section” (5 to 6 years old). Because of constraints to access a large number of schools,  our sample is defined a priori. We will have access to 21 classrooms of about 25 students (N = 525). We thus computed a sensitivity analysis (using G*Power software version 3.1) to estimate which effect size we would detect with 95% power for 1) the effect of SES (coded with two Helmert contrasts; model with 2 predictors) and 2) the interaction between SES and year (coded with two orthogonal contrasts; model with 8 predictors, see below for more details). The sensitivity analysis shows that a sample of 525 preschoolers would allow to detect a small to medium effect size for the effect of SES (d = 0.34) as well as for the interaction between SES and year (d = 0.42 ).
Data collection will stop when we will reach the desire sample size, namely 525 children.

(H13) Do the differences related to SES in the time children speak after “taking the floor” remain constant, are attenuated or amplified?

IV. SES will be coded with two Helmert contrasts as predictors (Brauer & McClelland, 2005), the first one comparing low-SES children (coded -2/3) to both middle-SES and high-SES children (coded +1/3) and the second one comparing middle-SES children (coded -0.5) to high-SES children (coded +0.5; low-SES being coded 0). Gender will be coded with one contrast that will allow us to compare oral participation of girls (coded -0.5) and boys (coded +0.5).  These contrasts will allow us to analyze the gender effect and the possible interaction between gender and SES by computing interactions between the two coded contrasts for SES (i.e., low-SES vs. [middle and high-SES] and middle-SES vs. high-SES). Concerning our explanatory analysis, year will be coded with two orthogonal contrasts, the first one comparing first year of preschool (coded -0.5) to third year of preschool (coded +0.5; second year coded 0) and the second one comparing second year (coded +2/3) to both first and third year (coded -1/3). These contrasts will allow us to analyze the possible attenuation and amplification of SES differences in oral participation throughout preschool by computing interactions between the two coded contrasts for SES (i.e., low-SES vs. [middle and high-SES] and middle-SES vs. high-SES) and the two orthogonal contrasts for year. Linear pattern of attenuation or amplification would be supported by a significant interaction with the first orthogonal contrast (i.e., first year vs. third year) and a non-significant interaction with the second orthogonal contrast (i.e., second year vs. [first-year and third-year]).

DV. 4 variables: (1) number of time children speak after being questioned, (2) number of times children speak without being questioned (sum of occurrences “speak without being questioned by the teacher”, “speak by interrupting another child” and “speak by interrupting the teacher”), (3) speaking time after being questioned and (4) speaking time without being questioned (sum of occurrences “speak without being questioned by the teacher”, “speak by interrupting another child” and “speak by interrupting the teacher”).

The analyses will be performed using the software program R (Version 3.4.3). Data will be analyzed with a generalized linear model with classroom-period fixed-effects using packages “MASS” (Venables & Ripley, 2002) and “lme4” (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). Observations are nested in periods of observation and classrooms therefore violating the assumption of independence of residuals. In such case, multi-level models can be used but they produce biased estimates with low numbers of higher-level units (Maas & Hox, 2005; Sommet & Morselli, 2017). We will perform fixed-effects models that remove all classroom-period variations and estimate the within classroom-period effects of SES on oral participation. To address heteroscedasticity, we will compute robust standard errors.

(H5 to H8) Gender will be our independent variable, while (1) number of time children speak after being questioned, (2) number of times children speak without being questioned, (3) speaking time after being questioned and (4) speaking time without being questioned will be used as our dependent variables. 

(H9 to H13) SES will be our independent variable, year will be our moderator, while (1) number of time children speak after being questioned, (2) number of times children speak without being questioned, (3) speaking time after being questioned and (4) speaking time without being questioned will be used as our dependent variables.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
We plan to exclude children with disabilities (i.e., any troubles that necessitate the presence of an educational assistance) and students that arrived in the country in the two years preceding data collection.

We will not use data-based or method-based outlier criteria

q1.value: Do predictability preferences in music correlate with autism or psychosis

q2.value: Robert Biegler, Rebekka Solvik Lisøy, Hans Fredrik Sunde, Gerit Pfuhl

q3.value: The overestimation of prediction error has been claimed to contribute to both psychosis (Frith, 2005) and autism (van de Cruys et al., 2014).  Further, music is supposed to have a sweet spot of complexity, where it is neither too predictably boring, nor too unpredictably chaotic (Gold et al., 2018, Predictive processing in music liking and arousal: influences of syntatctic and explicit music predictability).  Assuming equal preferences for the subjective experience of complexity and the corresponding prediction error, the overestimation of prediction error should lead to tendencies towards autism and psychosis correlating with preference for simpler music (Goris et al., 2019, The relation between preference for predictability and autistic traits).

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Greater tendencies towards autism, as measured by the 28-item form of the Autism Quotient questionnaire, correlate positively with a preference for simpler music.
Hypothesis 2: Greater tendencies towards psychosis, as measured by the positive items of the Community Assessment of Psychic Experiences (CAPE-42) questionnaire, correlate positively with a preference for simpler music.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We conduct a cohort study, with three questionnaires and one survey in which people rate how much they like each of 29 pieces of music.  The music is listed in the file "Music complexity.xlsx".

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We expect to recruit 80 to 100 students from UiT through fulfillment of course requirements.  Then we hope to increase the total to 150 participants by offering 150 NOK for participation.  Participants must be at least 18 years old, capable of informed consent to participate, and without hearing impairment,

q14.value: At the time we planned the experiment, no data were available to estimate effect size.  A power analysis of the intended way to estimate the most preferred complexity indicates that 150 participants give us a power of 0.499 to detect a correlation of 0.2 (for 50 pieces of music; we use 29), 0.671 for a correlation of 0.25, and 0.873 for a correlation of 0.3.  Since then, the results of Goris et al. indicate a correlation in the range of 0.2 for autism, though with a different measurement procedure.  That indicates we should ideally recruit more than 150 participants, but we do not currently have the resources to do so.

q15.value: At present, we have 7500 NOK available to spend on recruiting participants in addition to those who do the experiment for course requirements.  At 150 NOK per participant, that means up to 50 additional participants.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated.

Sum of responses to the CAPE-pos items
Sum of responses to the AQ-28 items
Liking for each of 29 pieces of music, listed in "Music complexity.xlsx"

Preferred complexity is estimated through a quadratic regression on the 29 ratings of pieces of music.  Provided that the quadratic component is -0.1 or smaller (meaning more different from 0), and that the maximum of the parabola fitted to the data is within the range of complexities of music played to participants, we take that maximum to be the preferred complexity.  If the quadratic component is between -0.1 and 0.1, and the linear slope is distinguishable from 0 at p < 0.05, the most extreme complexity on the more preferred side is taken to be the preferred complexity.  If either the quadratic component is larger than 0.1 or the linear slope cannot be distinguished from 0, that participant is excluded from analysis.  It is the preferred complexity, estimated as outlined here, which is correlated with other measures.  This analysis is valid if extrapolation to the preferred complexity is uncommon.  We choose a threshold of 20%

If the majority of individual data sets must be treated as linear, implying a preferred complexity outside of the range we present, then we will calculate intercepts, and correlate these with the other measures.
We will calculate partial correlations of preferred complexity with both the sum of CAPE-pos item scores and, separately, with the sum of AQ-28 item scores, controlling for ACE scores.

q20.value: If residuals are not normally distributed, we will seek a transformation that brings the distribution within an acceptable range.

q22.value: The software does not permit the omission of questions except for the Adverse Childhod Experiences questionnaire at the end.  We will exclude from analysis the data of people who stop answering before reaching the ACE, those who give a middle rating for liking music to more than 14 pieces of music, and those whose quadratic component in the stimation of preferred complexity is larger than 0.1, and those whos quadratic component is between -0.1 and 0.1 and who also show a linear slope indistinguishable from 0.

q23.value: People with data missing from parts of the experiment before the Adverse Childhood Experiences questionnaire will be excluded from analysis.  Those not reporting adverse childhood experiences will be treated as not having experienced any.

q24.value: If at least one of the correlations shows a positive result, we will enter both CAPE-pos scores and AQ-28 scores as predictors of preferred complexity in a multiple regression.

Then we hope to increase the total to 150 participants by offering 150 NOK for participation.  Participants must be at least 18 years old, capable of informed consent to participate, and without hearing impairment,
registration_responses.q16.question: No variables will be manipulated.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Sum of responses to the CAPE-pos items
Sum of responses to the AQ-28 items
Liking for each of 29 pieces of music, listed in "Music complexity.xlsx"
registration_responses.q18.question:
Preferred complexity is estimated through a quadratic regression on the 29 ratings of pieces of music.  Provided that the quadratic component is -0.1 or smaller (meaning more different from 0), and that the maximum of the parabola fitted to the data is within the range of complexities of music played to participants, we take that maximum to be the preferred complexity.  If the quadratic component is between -0.1 and 0.1, and the linear slope is distinguishable from 0 at p < 0.05, the most extreme complexity on the more preferred side is taken to be the preferred complexity.  If either the quadratic component is larger than 0.1 or the linear slope cannot be distinguished from 0, that participant is excluded from analysis.  It is the preferred complexity, estimated as outlined here, which is correlated with other measures.  This analysis is valid if extrapolation to the preferred complexity is uncommon.  We choose a threshold of 20%

If the majority of individual data sets must be treated as linear, implying a preferred complexity outside of the range we present, then we will calculate intercepts, and correlate these with the other measures.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will calculate partial correlations of preferred complexity with both the sum of CAPE-pos item scores and, separately, with the sum of AQ-28 item scores, controlling for ACE scores.

attributes.title: Do predictability preferences in music correlate with autism or psychosis

q1.value: Do predictability preferences in music correlate with autism or psychosis

q2.value: Robert Biegler, Rebekka Solvik Lisøy, Hans Fredrik Sunde, Gerit Pfuhl

q3.value: The overestimation of prediction error has been claimed to contribute to both psychosis (Frith, 2005) and autism (van de Cruys et al., 2014).  Further, music is supposed to have a sweet spot of complexity, where it is neither too predictably boring, nor too unpredictably chaotic (Gold et al., 2018, Predictive processing in music liking and arousal: influences of syntatctic and explicit music predictability).  Assuming equal preferences for the subjective experience of complexity and the corresponding prediction error, the overestimation of prediction error should lead to tendencies towards autism and psychosis correlating with preference for simpler music (Goris et al., 2019, The relation between preference for predictability and autistic traits).

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Greater tendencies towards autism, as measured by the 28-item form of the Autism Quotient questionnaire, correlate positively with a preference for simpler music.
Hypothesis 2: Greater tendencies towards psychosis, as measured by the positive items of the Community Assessment of Psychic Experiences (CAPE-42) questionnaire, correlate positively with a preference for simpler music.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We conduct a cohort study, with three questionnaires and one survey in which people rate how much they like each of 29 pieces of music.  The music is listed in the file "Music complexity.xlsx".

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We expect to recruit 80 to 100 students from UiT through fulfillment of course requirements.  Then we hope to increase the total to 150 participants by offering 150 NOK for participation.  Participants must be at least 18 years old, capable of informed consent to participate, and without hearing impairment,

q14.value: At the time we planned the experiment, no data were available to estimate effect size.  A power analysis of the intended way to estimate the most preferred complexity indicates that 150 participants give us a power of 0.499 to detect a correlation of 0.2 (for 50 pieces of music; we use 29), 0.671 for a correlation of 0.25, and 0.873 for a correlation of 0.3.  Since then, the results of Goris et al. indicate a correlation in the range of 0.2 for autism, though with a different measurement procedure.  That indicates we should ideally recruit more than 150 participants, but we do not currently have the resources to do so.

q15.value: At present, we have 7500 NOK available to spend on recruiting participants in addition to those who do the experiment for course requirements.  At 150 NOK per participant, that means up to 50 additional participants.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated.

Sum of responses to the CAPE-pos items
Sum of responses to the AQ-28 items
Liking for each of 29 pieces of music, listed in "Music complexity.xlsx"

Preferred complexity is estimated through a quadratic regression on the 29 ratings of pieces of music.  Provided that the quadratic component is -0.1 or smaller (meaning more different from 0), and that the maximum of the parabola fitted to the data is within the range of complexities of music played to participants, we take that maximum to be the preferred complexity.  If the quadratic component is between -0.1 and 0.1, and the linear slope is distinguishable from 0 at p < 0.05, the most extreme complexity on the more preferred side is taken to be the preferred complexity.  If either the quadratic component is larger than 0.1 or the linear slope cannot be distinguished from 0, that participant is excluded from analysis.  It is the preferred complexity, estimated as outlined here, which is correlated with other measures.  This analysis is valid if extrapolation to the preferred complexity is uncommon.  We choose a threshold of 20%

If the majority of individual data sets must be treated as linear, implying a preferred complexity outside of the range we present, then we will calculate intercepts, and correlate these with the other measures.
We will calculate partial correlations of preferred complexity with both the sum of CAPE-pos item scores and, separately, with the sum of AQ-28 item scores, controlling for ACE scores.

q20.value: If residuals are not normally distributed, we will seek a transformation that brings the distribution within an acceptable range.

q22.value: The software does not permit the omission of questions except for the Adverse Childhod Experiences questionnaire at the end.  We will exclude from analysis the data of people who stop answering before reaching the ACE, those who give a middle rating for liking music to more than 14 pieces of music, and those whose quadratic component in the stimation of preferred complexity is larger than 0.1, and those whos quadratic component is between -0.1 and 0.1 and who also show a linear slope indistinguishable from 0.

q23.value: People with data missing from parts of the experiment before the Adverse Childhood Experiences questionnaire will be excluded from analysis.  Those not reporting adverse childhood experiences will be treated as not having experienced any.

q24.value: If at least one of the correlations shows a positive result, we will enter both CAPE-pos scores and AQ-28 scores as predictors of preferred complexity in a multiple regression.
